problem_text:
(P. Longobardi, M. Maj, A. H. Rhemtulla). Let w = w(x1, . . . , xn) be a group word in n variables x1, . . . , xn, and V(w) the variety of groups defined by the law w = 1. Let V(w∗) (respectively, V(w#)) be the class of all groups G in which for every n infinite subsets S1, . . . , Sn there exist si ∈ Si such that w(s1, . . . , sn) = 1 (respectively, ⟨s1, . . . , sn⟩ ∈ V(w)).

a) Is there some word w and an infinite group G such that G ∈ V(w#) but G /∈ V(w)?

b) Is there some word w and an infinite group G such that G ∈ V(w∗) but G /∈ V(w#)?

The answer to both of these questions is likely to be “yes”. It is known that in a) w cannot be any of several words such as xn1, [x1, . . . , xn], [x1, x2]2, (x1x2)3x−3 2 x−3 1, and xa1 1 · · · xan n for any non-zero integers a1, . . . , an.

A. Abdollahi
